an6.37:1.2: Not sure why BB uses perfect here, the tense is the same as the next sentence.
an6.37:2.4: The nuance in the terms for positive emotions here is interesting. sumana is a more general sense of well-being, good mood. Pasada comes in the act of doing. While attamana is the result of something. I render the latter more literally, sometimes it just means “pleased”, but it usually refers to an uplifting emotion that results from something positive.
an6.37:6.4: I feel the translation misses something if the obvious allusion to Brahmanical sacrifice is lost.
